GameSpot News today acquired new details on the sequel to Capcom's fighting game Marvel vs. Capcom. Titled Marvel vs. Capcom 2: New Age of Heroes, the game will sport a three-on-three team-battle mode similar to the team-system battle mode in the King of Fighters series. The "variable combination" from the first game will now have all three characters performing a mix of super combos. There will also be a new combo called "de-raid hyper combo," which involves all three characters as well.

The new characters on the Capcom side are Sonson (from Sonson), Hayato (from Star Gladiator), and an original character named Amingo. On the Marvel side, newcomers are Cable, Marrow, Doctor Doom, and an original character called Ruby Heart. Old characters such as Ryu, Guile, Zangief, Strider, Cyclops, Captain America, Wolverine, and Venom will be returning to the respective rosters as well.

The game is scheduled to appear in the arcades in spring 2000 and on the Sega Dreamcast shortly thereafter. The arcade and Dreamcast can be linked together using the Visual Memory Unit, although what purpose it will serve has not been revealed. GameSpot News will keep you posted.
results.lede: Capcom unleashes new characters and gameplay in the sequel to Marvel vs. Capcom 2.

results.title: Nintendo Selects Ultimate PokeMOM
results.deck: Nintendo's nationwide online contest to find the Ultimate PokeMOM concludes.
results.body:
Nintendo of America announced on Wednesday that its nationwide online contest to find the "Ultimate PokeMOM" has come to a conclusion. After searching through more than 16,000 entries, the company has declared Diane Bergquist of Bellingham, Wash., the "Ultimate PokeMOM."

Mrs. Bergquist was chosen for her high scores in such categories as Poke-dedication and Poke-knowledge. As the winner of the contest she will receive a day of pampering and a US$1,000 shopping spree in New York City. Also, her family will ride around Manhattan in an official Pokemobile - a VW beetle that has been customized to resemble the popular Pokemon character Pikachu.

"It was an extremely tough decision for us to pick the winner. The winning essays were heartfelt and entertaining. We could have easily awarded all of the semifinalists the Ultimate PokeMOM ," said Gail Tilden, Nintendo's vice president of product development and acquisition. "It's obvious from the overwhelming number of responses that parents have joined in the fun of the Pokemon craze and have enjoyed learning the games and the characters' special skills together with their kids."
results.lede: Nintendo's nationwide online contest to find the Ultimate PokeMOM concludes.

results.title: PS SimTheme Park In March
results.deck: EA is getting ready to bring its popular PC-based amusement park builder to the PlayStation.
results.body:
Electronic Arts has announced that SimTheme Park, developed by UK-based Bullfrog Studios, will be coming to the PlayStation console in March 2000. The new version gives players the chance to construct a complete amusement park with rides (from massive roller coasters to bump-and-run go-carts), shops, concession stands, and more. And to spice it up, the game will have four themes - Space Zone, Lost Kingdom, Land of Wonders, and Halloween - to choose from.

The PlayStation version of the game will come complete with an easy-to-use interface, along with analog and dual-shock support.
results.lede: EA is getting ready to bring its popular PC-based amusement park builder to the PlayStation.

results.title: GBC Test Drive Off-Road 3 Ships
results.deck: Infogrames announces that Test Drive Off-Road 3 for the Game Boy Color platform has shipped to stores.
results.body:
Infogrames announced on Wednesday that Test Drive Off-Road 3 for the Nintendo Game Boy Color platform has shipped to stores. The game released on the PlayStation console earlier this fall.

"Test Drive Off-Road 3 gives gamers the ultimate off-road racing experience right in the palm of their hands," said Laddie Ervin, director of product marketing for sports and racing at Infogrames North America. "With the combination of real licensed vehicles and real-world locations, it is the best bet for a Game Boy gamer."

According to Infogrames, Test Drive Off-Road 3 for the GBC combines real-world vehicles (such as the Dodge Ram V12 and the Jeep Wrangler) with arcade-style play. The game should be arriving in stores this week.
results.lede: Infogrames announces that Test Drive Off-Road 3 for the Game Boy Color platform has shipped to stores.

results.title: First Look: Earth 2150
results.deck: We've got screens and impressions on an RTS that's all the rage in Europe.
results.body:
There's a game that's currently creating a lot of hype in Europe: Earth 2150. Developed in Germany, this real-time strategy game is setting the magazines on fire. Comments like "best strategy game of the year" and constant marks around 90 percent indicate that this title could be a blockbuster once it lands on US shores.

Distributed by Mattel/Mindscape and developed by Topware, the title is set for a Q2 release in the States. As of now, we have a handful of screenshots and will soon be following up with an interview with the development team.

The game features true 3D terrain, which means that you'll have to plan things like troops movements very carefully, as explosions and the like can change the landscape dramatically. There are a total of 90 missions and three races available for the player to choose from. Additionally there will be many sub-missions and tasks to complete within the missions themselves. A map editor is also provided, in case players get bored with the maps included in the game.

We'll report further on the game as its US release date approaches. In the meantime, enjoy these shots.
results.lede: We've got screens and impressions on an RTS that's all the rage in Europe.

results.title: Nvidia Sues S3
results.deck: The latest lawsuit to hit Silicon Valley is shrouded in mystery.
results.body:
Earlier this morning, GameSpot News learned that 3D-chip manufacturer Nvidia has sued crosstown rival S3. The lawsuit was apparently served earlier this week; however, both companies were hoping to avoid any press and have been tight-lipped on the subject.

According to S3, Nvidia's lawsuit is "vague" and seems to focus on an audio patent and not transform and lighting as previously reported. Needless to say, this seems more than a little strange, as Nvidia is exclusively a graphics company and has announced no plans to develop any audio solutions whatsoever.

An S3 representative told GameSpot News that this lawsuit is a negotiation tactic to get S3 to settle on the outstanding graphics-patent suit filed against Nvidia by S3 in 1998. That case is supposed to go to trial in February of 2000. Nvidia officials were unavailable for comment at press time. Look to GameSpot News to bring you more details as they become available.
results.lede: The latest lawsuit to hit Silicon Valley is shrouded in mystery.

results.title: Millionaire Still on Top
results.deck: Disney Interactive's PC game seems to be just as successful as the TV quiz show.
results.body:
PC Data's latest sales figures are in, and the results aren't very surprising. Disney Interactive's Who Wants to be a Millionaire maintained its hold as the top-selling PC game for the week ending December 11, extending its reign to two weeks. Hasbro's Roller Coaster Tycoon jumped to second place, spurred by the release of the Corkscrew Follies expansion pack.

The only newcomer to the list this week was Hasbro's Frogger, a 3D remake of Konami's original arcade game. It's interesting to note that of the ten games on this week's list, seven retail for under US$30.

PC Data's Top Ten Hits List is as follows:

Rank / Title / Publisher / Price1 / Who Wants To Be A Millionaire / Disney / $192 / MP Roller Coaster Tycoon / Hasbro Interactive / $263 / Barbie Generation Girl Gotta Groove / Mattel Interactive / $294 / Microsoft Age of Empires II: Age Of Kings / Microsoft / $435 / Quake III Arena / Activision / $496 / Toy Story 2 Action Game / Disney / $257 / Deer Hunter III / GT Interactive / $198 / Frogger / Hasbro Interactive / $199 / Cabela's Big Game Hunter 3 / Activision / $1810 / Microsoft Flight Simulator / Microsoft / $43
results.lede: Disney Interactive's PC game seems to be just as successful as the TV quiz show.

results.title: Take-Two's Holiday Is a Good One
results.deck: Sales expectations meet or exceed Take-Two's expectations for the holiday season.
results.body:
Take-Two Interactive announced Thursday that it has had a good holiday season globally so far, with continuing strong sales all around the world.

"Take-Two continues to be pleased with sales results from its published products worldwide, as well as sales levels from its Jack of All Games value-added distribution and budget publishing divisions around the globe," said Take-Two's CEO Ryan Brant.
results.lede: Sales expectations meet or exceed Take-Two's expectations for the holiday season.

results.title: Carrier Due February
results.deck: Jaleco's Resident Evil-style adventure game is coming to the Dreamcast this February.
results.body: Today GameSpot News learned the release date of Carrier for the Sega Dreamcast. Developed by Jaleco, the action-adventure game is similar in style to Resident Evil and Parasite Eve and will be compatible with the VGA box and the Jump Pack. Carrier is expected to ship on February 24, 2000, in Japan.
results.lede: Jaleco's Resident Evil-style adventure game is coming to the Dreamcast this February.

results.title: Final Fantasy IX Animation Done
results.deck: According to sources at Square's Honolulu studio, animation for the upcoming FFIX has been completed.
results.body:
Sources at Square's Honolulu studio have informed GameSpot News that CG animation for Final Fantasy IX for the PlayStation has been completed. The team has been working rigorously over the past few weeks, even over the Thanksgiving break, to complete the animation. However, now that work has been finished, Square is apparently releasing many of the team members.

According to some, this has caused a negative reaction amongst the animation designers who had hoped to continue the same work once the project wrapped. Square doesn't see it that way, though. "Employment contracts for all game designers and CG graphic artists at the Square USA Honolulu studio are negotiated on an individual-game basis from the beginning of the project," stated a company spokesperson. "Much like in the film industry, game production is controlled by development phases, such as pre-production, production, and editing. This method is the most efficient and allows effective control of all phases of development."

The Square spokesperson went on to say, "For this reason, once an individual phase has been completed, parts of the team may be disbanded while the game is still in development. However, because of the detailed schedule management described above, such events do not affect the development schedule in any way."

Square conducted similar practices after the animation was completed for Parasite Eve for the PlayStation, the company's first game developed in Honolulu. Team members from that project went on to work on other games, and some got involved with the Final Fantasy movie. Square commented that "the current plan for the Honolulu studio teams that are disbanded are either reassigned to the Honolulu movie team or relocated to Japan to work on the next generation of games."

Final Fantasy IX for the PlayStation is currently slated for release sometime in the spring of 2000 in Japan and likely in the fall of 2000 in the US. Previously, sources had indicated to GameSpot News that Square was shooting for a 9/9/99 release date for the game in Japan, but many aspects of the project took longer than expected.
results.lede: According to sources at Square's Honolulu studio, animation for the upcoming FFIX has been completed.

results.title: Nintendo Wins Piracy Battle
results.deck: A US Federal Court deals a blow against software piracy.
results.body:
Nintendo's battle against Hong Kong-based manufacturer Bung Enterprises Ltd. was apparently victorious Thursday when a US Federal Court awarded Nintendo more than US$7 million in damages plus interest.

Bung, which creates products such as the Game Doctor series, allows the copying of Nintendo's game products from the cartridge to the computer where it can be distributed illegally. An injunction has been issued that prevents Bung from selling these products in North, Central, and South America.

Apparently Bung was not very cooperative during the discovery process, which did not help its case.

"Throughout the litigation Bung demonstrated nothing but contempt for the American judicial system and continued to develop and market products that were designed to permit the pirating of video game software of Nintendo and its third-party publishers," said Richard Flamm, Nintendo's General Counsel. "We are very pleased the court has resoundingly condemned Bung's conduct and confirmed the infringing nature of Bung's products."
results.lede: A US Federal Court deals a blow against software piracy.

results.title: Tyson's Return to Video Gaming
results.deck: Codemasters signs Mike Tyson to appear in an upcoming PC and PlayStation boxing game.
results.body:
This morning, UK-based Codemasters announced that controversial heavyweight boxer Mike Tyson has been licensed to appear in the company's upcoming Mike Tyson Boxing. Under development for the PC and PlayStation, Mike Tyson Boxing will focus solely on Tyson and include training and career-management modes of play. Codemasters representatives told GameSpot News that Mike Tyson Boxing will actually be a localized version of Prince Naseem Boxing, already released in Europe.

"Believe it or not, it's my kids who have been after me to get a game going for quite a while now, and I've been watching this whole area of sports-based computer and video games, waiting for just the right opportunity to become involved," said Tyson. "Codemasters brought to the table a long string of hit games and showed me that they've got what it takes to make a boxing game that I'm proud to put my name on."

Tyson's last video-game appearance was for Nintendo's Mike Tyson Punch-Out for the original Nintendo Entertainment System back in 1986. Mike Tyson Boxing is expected to ship next May for both platforms.
results.lede: Codemasters signs Mike Tyson to appear in an upcoming PC and PlayStation boxing game.

results.title: VIA To Buy S3
results.deck: Taiwanese core-logic chipset manufacturer VIA plans on purchasing S3 in a deal worth nearly $150 million.
results.body:
Over the holiday weekend, VIA technologies, a popular Taiwanese manufacturer of core-logic chipsets, announced plans to purchase S3. The deal, worth nearly US$150 million, calls for VIA to purchase 10.8 million shares of S3 stock at $13.50 per share and increases the company's equity in S3 to 14.9 percent.

"The investment by VIA Technologies in S3 is yet another demonstration of the growing collaboration between our two companies," said S3 CEO Ken Potashner. "The technology and IP available between our two companies have positioned us to aggressively compete in the value PC segment through the strategy of integrating our technologies."

The deal is still subject to approval by various shareholder and government bodies, but it is expected to go through.
results.lede: Taiwanese core-logic chipset manufacturer VIA plans on purchasing S3 in a deal worth nearly $150 million.

results.title: Werewolf Development Updated
results.deck: ASC Games updates its web site with the development status of Werewolf: The Apocalypse.
results.body:
Late last week ASC Games producer Travis Williams posted a Werewolf: The Apocalypse development update on his company's web site. Willaims talks about level design and object placement in Werewolf, delves into some of the game's sounds and music, and posts four new screenshots to illustrate his examples.

Werewolf was recently surrounded by rumors of delay and cancellation. ASC has since squashed any such rumors and insists that the game's development is progressing as planned.
results.lede: ASC Games updates its web site with the development status of Werewolf: The Apocalypse.

results.title: Game Boy Titles Coming in March
results.deck: Warioland 3 and the first Legend of Zelda: Fushigina Kinomi for the GBC are heading to Japan this March.
results.body:
GameSpot News today received word from Nintendo of Japan that it will release Warioland 3 and Legend of Zelda: Fushigina Kinomi (Mysterious Fruit of Tree, in English) for the Game Boy Color this coming March. Warioland 3 is the first Wario-action game to appear on the colored version of the handheld console. As for Zelda, it is the first of three chapters in the Fushigina Kinomi series that are being codeveloped for the GBC by Nintendo and Capcom.

Warioland 3 and Legend of Zelda: Fushigina Kinomi are both slated for a March 2000 release in Japan.
results.lede: Warioland 3 and the first Legend of Zelda: Fushigina Kinomi for the GBC are heading to Japan this March.

results.title: Koei Fights For Second PS2 Title
results.deck: Koei and Omega Force bring the Romance of the Three Kingdoms fighting game onto PlayStation2.
results.body:
GameSpot News today learned that Koei is developing the sequel to Sangoku Musou, the fighting game based on the Romance of the Three Kingdoms series. Simply titled Shin Sangoku Musou, the game is being developed by Omega Force, which has previously worked on Sangoku Musou (PS) and WinBack (N64).

No release date or price has been set at this point. Meanwhile, Koei's first title Kessen is scheduled for a March 4, 2000, release - simultaneous with the PS2 launch in Japan.
results.lede: Koei and Omega Force bring the Romance of the Three Kingdoms fighting game onto PlayStation2.

results.title: Seventh Cross Sequel Confirmed
results.deck: NEC Home Electronics has confirmed that a sequel to Seventh Cross is currently in development.
results.body: GameSpot News learned today that a sequel to Seventh Cross is currently in development. Titled Ninth Will, the Dreamcast game is being developed by NEC Home Electronics. No Japanese release date or price has been disclosed at this point. Whether a distributor will bring it to the overseas market is unknown. We'll keep you posted.
results.lede: NEC Home Electronics has confirmed that a sequel to Seventh Cross is currently in development.

results.title: UK To Levy Game Tax?
results.deck: BBC News is reporting that UK government officials are pushing for a video-game tax to fund higher learning.
results.body:
BBC News is reporting that certain members of the British Labour Party are pushing for a law that would impose a 50p (about US80 cents) tax on sales of all video games. Why? Because the country's Prime Minister, Tony Blair, has stated that he would like half of all UK citizens between the ages of 18 and 30 to participate in higher learning by the year 2007. Bigger grants would be required for a venture of this caliber, and as such, certain Labour Party representatives have pointed at the UK's video-game industry as a possible source of that needed income.

"These are not taxed at the moment, and they are therefore a reasonable target to consider," said Mr. Marsden, one of the Labour Party's representatives, in the BBC article.

Video games account for over US$800 million in sales in the UK, and this proposed tax (about 1 percent of each unit's total cost) would yield around $8 million annually. As of now, there's no word on whether or not the British government plans on passing this law.
results.lede: BBC News is reporting that UK government officials are pushing for a video-game tax to fund higher learning.

results.title: First Impressions: Warp's D2
results.deck: D2 for the Dreamcast has arrived - check out new media and impressions of the final game.
results.body:
Over the weekend we received our copy of WARP's long-delayed D2 and had a chance to play it for a few hours. While the game is technically impressive and sports high-production values, D2's gameplay unfortunately doesn't stray too far from that of the original D, leaving us a little disappointed.

Following WARP's quirky animated logo, players are taken directly to a menu screen. Interestingly enough, the opening movie is an option rather than a prerequisite to playing the game - a good thing, since it resides on the game's fourth disc. The opening movie centers on a flight carrying Laura, the game's heroine. A seemingly normal flight is disturbed when some unknown assailants hijack the plane. Despite the chaos, a gnarled old man chants dark incantations in the back of the plane. David, the man sitting across the aisle from Laura, sees a vision in Laura's compact, a gift from her mother, showing a meteor hurtling toward the plane. The meteor strikes the plane. The next thing Laura knows, she's in a cabin with a woman named Kimberly in the snowy depths of Canada.

From here, players are given control of Laura. Laura's lost her memory and, thus, must perform a variety of little errands for Kimberly. Many of these errands involve running from one end of Canada to another to pick up various items, something seemingly taken from Zelda 64's lacking overworld. As Laura runs about, she is randomly attacked by an array of plant-like mutants. Battle is conducted in a first-person hybrid of Quake and House of the Dead, requiring players to move Laura's Uzi's sight around the screen and plant ammo on the attacking monsters. In addition to fighting monsters, Laura can also hunt for food with a sniper rifle, bringing a whole new meaning to the "survival" aspect of survival horror.

The game's indoor locales take place in a first-person perspective as well. However, except in a few instances, Laura can only move her gaze to predetermined locations. From these locations players can move Laura's sight slightly letting her spot other points of minor interest. This is a little frustrating, however, as many times you can see items and not figure out how to look at them to pick them up.

D2's graphics are impressive throughout. The characters and environments are lavishly textured and detailed, and the character animation is impressive considering that it's not motion-captured. Additionally, all of the extensive character voices are nicely lip-synched. In addition to the voices, the music subtly enhances the air of mystery.

While the production is great and all, you can't skirt around the fact that D2 is currently shaping up to be an extremely linear, gameplay-poor adventure game like the original.
results.lede: D2 for the Dreamcast has arrived - check out new media and impressions of the final game.

results.title: DC Vigilante 8: Second Offense Ships
results.deck: Activision announces that the Dreamcast version of Vigilante 8: Second Offense has shipped to stores nationwide.
results.body:
Activision announced on Tuesday that Vigilante 8: Second Offense for the Sega Dreamcast has shipped to stores. The game was previously released for the PlayStation last month, and a Nintendo 64 version will hit stores in January (according to sources, the N64 version hit snags in production).

"Vigilante 8: Second Offense is the must-have, auto-combat title of the year," stated Mitch Lasky, executive vice president of Activision Studios. "The game delivers all the breakthrough elements of Vigilante 8 and ups the ante by further redefining the auto-combat genre with its morphing vehicle advancements. "

Vigilante 8: Second Offense for the Dreamcast should be available in stores nationwide this week at a suggested price of US$49.95.
results.lede: Activision announces that the Dreamcast version of Vigilante 8: Second Offense has shipped to stores nationwide.

results.title: Vatical Releases Dreamcast E.G.G.
results.deck: Vatical Entertainment announces that Elemental Gimmick Gear (E.G.G.) for the Sega Dreamcast has shipped to stores.
results.body:
Vatical Entertainment announced on Tuesday that Elemental Gimmick Gear (E.G.G.) for the Sega Dreamcast has shipped to stores. As one of the first RPG titles for the Dreamcast console, E.G.G. comes as a welcome addition, to many DC owners.

Videogames.com's Ike Sato recently reviewed the import version of the game, scoring it a 6.8. For his review, click on the link to the right.
results.lede: Vatical Entertainment announces that Elemental Gimmick Gear (E.G.G.) for the Sega Dreamcast has shipped to stores.

results.title: Spike Saves Human
results.deck: Spike has saved the now-bankrupt Human with newly established subsidiary company Vile.
results.body:
GameSpot News received word today that Japanese game developer Spike has officially established a new subsidiary company called Vile. The subsidiary will help save developer Human's staff by recruiting 60 of its members into the new company.

Human, known for games such as Clock Tower, declared bankruptcy last November. The capital of the company is funded at 30 million yen (about US$293,000). Vile will focus on development of game software and Internet content with Spike as the publisher. Vile has already been involved in recent projects with Spike, such as the PlayStation cult-hit racing title Bakusou Dekotora Densetsu 2.
results.lede: Spike has saved the now-bankrupt Human with newly established subsidiary company Vile.

results.title: Mindscape Ships New GBC Titles
results.deck: Mindscape announces two new titles for the Game Boy Color have shipped to stores: Dogz and Wings of Fury.
results.body:
Mindscape announced on Tuesday that it has shipped two new titles for the Game Boy: Dogz and Wings of Fury. Dogz is based on the popular PC title of the same name, and it lets players interact with virtual pets that inhabit the Game Boy. The title supports the link cable and lets gamers collect items from others. Mindscape's other title, Wings of Fury, is also based on a PC game of the same name. It lets the player assume the role of an F6F Hellcat fighter-plane pilot and offers players missions to accomplish.

Both games should be arriving on store shelves this week.
results.lede: Mindscape announces two new titles for the Game Boy Color have shipped to stores: Dogz and Wings of Fury.

results.title: First Impressions: Shen Mue
results.deck: Arguably one of the most anticipated Sega games of all time, Shen Mue arrives at videogames.com. Check out our impressions.
results.body:
Finally, it's here. Over the holiday weekend we managed to get our hands on Shen Mue, Yu Suzuki's new FREE game (FREE, of course, stands for Full Reactive Eyes Entertainment - no, we don't know what that means either). After playing the game for a few days now, we have the first impressions here from the finished Japanese version of Chapter 1: Yokosuka.

The story revolves around the murder of your father and the theft of a mystic talisman by a mysterious Chinese man named Souryu. The story unfolds with stunning real-time cinema sequences. Although they don't display the level of detail present in the E3 Face demos, they are still a sight to behold. Yokosuka, the setting for this chapter in the Shen Mue saga, is also beautifully rendered. Obviously, you cannot enter every house, but when you do step inside a house there are a lot of objects to inspect and use. Virtually anything can be picked up. You can even take pictures off the walls of your home if you so wish (although why you'd want to is another matter entirely). The only problem with the graphics is a rather odd one.For some reason, some characters fade in while you are right in front of them. It's not even at any large distance either - I was having a conversation with someone when another character faded in right next to me!

Shen Mue's gameplay seems to resemble some of the old LucasArts PC adventures (Monkey Island, Full Throttle) in many ways, except that pointing-and-clicking has been replaced by a different interface. You comb areas for clues and look for objects to pick up and people to talk to. The dreaded Quick Time Events, where you simply press buttons when instructed (like Dynamite Cop), are surprisingly few and far between, allaying fears of Shen Mue becoming a second Dragon's Lair. There is also a "free battle" mode, where in more traditional Yu Suzuki fashion you fight against various opponents. Ryo is an expert martial artist and can also learn more moves from other people to increase his skill. This though is where Shen Mue is similar to the old PC adventure games, because the action sequences here are clearly separated sections that do not tend to interfere with the main exploration element.

One bright aspect of the game is the control. The digital pad moves Ryo; the analog stick moves his head (and thus his view); and, in an innovative touch, the R trigger acts as a special "focus" button. Holding the button and pointing in the general direction of an item will let Ryo focus on the item and then manipulate it, whether that means picking it up and moving it around or using it. The digital pad is somewhat clumsy (turning on the spot is quite hard for Ryo), but in all other aspects it is top-notch.

The game also has some nice extras. Right at the start of the game you find a virtual pet, of sorts - a kitten. You can use the kitten as a diversion - you care for it by petting it and bringing it food. In fact, the game has a lot of diversions. There is an arcade in town with classic games such as Hang On for you to try your hand at, as well as the infamous darts game and a QTE game. Don't want to go that far? Right underneath Ryo's TV is a Sega Saturn. If you're wondering what a Saturn is doing in 1986, you'll probably also wonder why you can get little Virtua Fighter and Sonic the Hedgehog toys from vending machines.

At this early stage, the only major problem I've encountered is that the plot advances rather slowly. Sure, the game world has a lot going on, and a lot can be done in Shen Mue's Yokosuka, but in terms of plot there is little to do - it almost feels like a tech demo; at times you won't know what to do, and you'll walk through a beautiful city rather aimlessly. Bear in mind though that I am still in the very early stages of the game, and everything could be about to change.

Stay tuned to videogames.com for more screens and information on Shen Mue throughout this week.
results.lede: Arguably one of the most anticipated Sega games of all time, Shen Mue arrives at videogames.com. Check out our impressions.

results.title: Sony's Network Console In 2001
results.deck: Sony plans to release a new line of audio-visual components that will link all its hardware, including the PlayStation2.
results.body:
Nikkei Online reports that Sony is currently developing a new line of network capable audiovisual components that can be controlled through a television set. These include digital television models, digital VCRs, DVD players, audio components, and most importantly for gamers, the PlayStation2. These will also have network capabilities that let users access the Internet for online shopping and technical support.

Sony plans to release these new audiovisual components in 2001. Meanwhile, Sony's next-generation video-game console, the PlayStation2, is scheduled for release on March 4, 2000. It will be interesting to see what plans lie ahead with the PlayStation2 linked to other Sony hardware. Stay tuned.
results.lede: Sony plans to release a new line of audio-visual components that will link all its hardware, including the PlayStation2.

results.title: New Elite Force Screenshots
results.deck: Raven Software updates its Star Trek: Voyager - Elite Force site with new info and screenshots.
results.body:
Raven Software's Kenn Hoekstra updated his plan file last night with word that the official Voyager - Elite Force web site has been updated with new information pertaining to the game's weapons, characters, and aliens. The update includes new screenshots and artwork of the game, as well as summaries for each of the game's main characters and alien classes.

Elite Force is a first-person shooter that uses the Quake III Arena engine to supply the game with its lush visuals. The game is expected to ship later in 2000.
results.lede: Raven Software updates its Star Trek: Voyager - Elite Force site with new info and screenshots.

results.title: Interstate '82 Map Editor Released
results.deck: Players can now create and customize their own I'82 tracks.
results.body:
Late last afternoon, Activision released the Interstate '82 Terraformer, a map editor that lets users customize their own maps and multiplayer scenarios. The editor, created by and for the design team, has both 2D and 3D views for easy manipulation of onscreen objects, as well as a tool for creating and tweaking vehicle AI.

The 18-megabyte download is linked to the right.
results.lede: Players can now create and customize their own I'82 tracks.

results.title: Brother Killed Over Game
results.deck: A 15-year-old boy in Kentucky has been charged with killing his brother over a video game.
results.body: Yahoo news has reported that a 15-year-old Kentucky boy has been charged with killing his brother over a video game. According to police, 14-year-old Andre Hardin was shot by his brother at their Louisville home. The name of the older brother and what game software sparked the attack have not been revealed.
results.lede: A 15-year-old boy in Kentucky has been charged with killing his brother over a video game.

results.title: DC Typing of the Dead Coming March
results.deck: The typing-tutorial game based on House of the Dead is heading to the Dreamcast in Japan this March.
results.body:
GameSpot News learned today that Sega of Japan will be releasing The Typing of the Dead: Keyboard Masters for the Dreamcast console next year. The game is similar to The House of the Dead except you kill zombies by typing text messages using the keyboard instead of firing the Dreamcast light gun.

The Typing of the Dead: Keyboard Masters is slated for a March 30, 2000, release, and it will carry a price tag of 4800yen (about US$47) in Japan.
results.lede: The typing-tutorial game based on House of the Dead is heading to the Dreamcast in Japan this March.

results.title: M2 D2 Movie Discovered
results.deck: While playing D2 we discover a secret movie - a video from the original M2 version of the game.
results.body:
As a few of you may remember, D2 developer, Warp, released a game called Real Sound 2 some time last year for the Sega Dreamcast in Japan. Since the game was 100 percent audio with no visuals, it wouldn't be much of a surprise if none of you bought it. However, it did have one thing to recommend it, and that was the D2 Shock demo. If you played through the demo's minigames, it would install a D2 shock game-save on your VMU. What this was good for no one knew. Now that we have the final version of D2 in our hands, we have discovered why.

Although there are different levels of success possible in the Shock demo, the game-save we had on our VMU unlocked a secret movie on disc 2 of D2 that revealed a CG-rendered movie that none of us had ever seen. In fact, after checking through Warp's home page, we learned that this is actually a movie scene from the cancelled M2 version of the game! (The M2 was a system from 3DO and Matsushita that was never released.) We'll be going back to the Shock demo for some more play time in the hopes that we can unlock some more funky stuff. If and when we do, we'll be back to report on it. In the meanwhile, stay tuned for the full D2 review coming soon.
results.lede: While playing D2 we discover a secret movie - a video from the original M2 version of the game.

results.title: New PlayStation2 Evergrace Screens
results.deck: We get our hands on a few more screens of Evergrace, one of From Software's visually impressions PS2 launch titles.
results.body: On its Japanese web site, From Software has released two new screens and a logo of Evergrace for the PlayStation2. The game is currently slated to release alongside the PlayStation2 on March 4, 2000, in Japan. Enjoy the new shots, and for some great-looking hi-res screens of Evergrace, click on the link to the right.
results.lede: We get our hands on a few more screens of Evergrace, one of From Software's visually impressions PS2 launch titles.

results.title: Hudson Announces DC Network RPG
results.deck: Hudson announces its new network RPG titled Rune Jade for the Sega Dreamcast.
results.body: Hudson of Japan today announced that it will be releasing a network RPG for the Sega Dreamcast. Called Rune Jade, the game will be an addition to the current list of Dreamcast network RPGs, including Baldur's Gate and Phantasy Star Online. No other details have been revealed at this point, but GameSpot News will keep you posted. Stay tuned.
results.lede: Hudson announces its new network RPG titled Rune Jade for the Sega Dreamcast.

results.title: Interact Gets Sega Blessing
results.deck: Interact Accessories announces that it will soon team up with Sega to produce officially licensed peripherals for the Dreamcast.
results.body:
Interact Accessories announced on Wednesday that it will soon partner with Sega of Japan and Sega of America to develop licensed accessories for the Dreamcast console. The company has sent a signed letter of intent to Sega and expects to release a formal announcement of the partnership. in mid-January. Reportedly, peripherals for the year 2000 from Interact will include proprietary technology and feedback provided directly from Sega.

"We're looking forward to receiving a license from Sega to produce Dreamcast accessories," said Todd Hays, InterAct's founder and president. "The Dreamcast has been an awesome success in North America and Europe, with more than 1.5 million units sold before the 1999 holiday season reached its peak.

Interact's current line of Dreamcast peripherals includes the Fission Fishing Controller, the StarFighter LightBlaster, and the AstroPad.
results.lede: Interact Accessories announces that it will soon team up with Sega to produce officially licensed peripherals for the Dreamcast.

results.title: New PlayStation2 Kessen Screens
results.deck: Japanese publisher Koei releases some great new screens of its PlayStation 2 war-themed strategy title Kessen.
results.body:
Koei has released some new screens of its war-themed PlayStation2 strategy title, Kessen. A launch title for the PlayStation2, Kessen features stunning cinema sequences that are accomplished in real time as well as some CG-rendered sequences. Whether or not these screens are prerendered or in real time is currently unknown, as both formats look virtually identical thanks to the powerful PlayStation2 hardware.

Enjoy these new shots, and for a whole bunch more, click on the links to the right.
results.lede: Japanese publisher Koei releases some great new screens of its PlayStation 2 war-themed strategy title Kessen.

results.title: More PlayStation2 Kessen Screens
results.deck: Browse through another set of new screens of the PlayStation 2 war-themed strategy title, Kessen.
results.body: In addition to the first batch of Kessen screens we posted in our first story today, we've got another batch straight from Koei's Japanese web site. Enjoy these new screens, and check out our link to the right for movies of the game in action.
results.lede: Browse through another set of new screens of the PlayStation 2 war-themed strategy title, Kessen.

results.title: Konami Arcade Classics Released
results.deck: Konami's arcade classics package for the Sony PlayStation has been released to stores.
results.body:
Konami announced on Thursday that its Konami Arcade Classics title for the Sony PlayStation has been released to stores. The game features ten classic arcade favorites in one package: Pooyan, Scramble, Super Cobra, Yie Ar Kung-Fu, Roc 'n' Rope, Shao-Lin's Road, Circus Charlie, Road Fighter, Time Pilot, and Gyruss.

"Konami Arcade Classics gives new players a taste of what first put Konami on the map while giving old pros their fix for '80's style arcade fun," said Chris Mike, Konami's director of marketing. "1999 is the perfect time to breathe new life into these classic favorites as we get ready to roll into a new millennium of entertaining games."

Konami Arcade Classics is currently available at stores nationwide at a suggested retail price of US$29.99.
results.lede: Konami's arcade classics package for the Sony PlayStation has been released to stores.

results.title: Quebec Threatens Nintendo and Sony
results.deck: The Quebec provincial government threatens to sue Nintendo and Sony if they don't provide French-language versions of games.
results.body:
The Quebec provincial government has threatened to sue Nintendo and Sony if the companies do not provide French-language versions of their games by New Year's Eve. French-language minister Louise Beaudoin told reporters on Thursday that after 18 months of discussion with representatives from the two companies she has threatened not to allow the games into Quebec (Canada's only French-speaking province).

"I am launching an ultimatum," said Beaudoin. "I conclude that it is time to act and to consider that negotiations have not been successful. The law must be applied."

So far, Beaudoin has only stated a legal warning, but she will file suits, if need be. "I hope we will not reach that stage,'' she continued.
results.lede: The Quebec provincial government threatens to sue Nintendo and Sony if they don't provide French-language versions of games.

results.title: BattleTech Signs 10,000 In Beta Test
results.deck: Kesmai's GameStorm attracts 10,000 beta testers to its upcoming MultiPlayer BattleTech: 3025 game.
results.body:
Kesmai has announced that it has registered 10,000 testers for its upcoming massively multiplayer futuristic strategy war title, MultiPlayer BattleTech: 3025. But those gamers will have to wait until early next year to begin testing. The game puts players in massive Mechs in the 31st century to battle for domination of the 2,000 worlds of the Inner Sphere. As a warrior in one of the five Great Houses battling for control, players start out as novices and work their way through the ranks as they take down opponents and gain experience.

As part of getting more gamers interested in the game, Kesmai's online gaming service, GameStorm, will be hosting a live chat on December 12 at 9pm EST. During the chat, gamers will get to ask the game's makers about the game and what they'll see when it is complete.

The complete game will release later next year, and it is expected to support upward of 50,000 players. Considering EA will probably have acquired Kesmai from News Corp by next year, the title could get additional marketing and design support from the big publisher.
results.lede: Kesmai's GameStorm attracts 10,000 beta testers to its upcoming MultiPlayer BattleTech: 3025 game.

results.title: Viper II DVD Bundle
results.deck: Diamond's Viper II will now be bundled with five Infogrames games on one DVD disc.
results.body:
This morning, Infogrames announced the five games it will bundle with Diamond's Savage2000-powered Viper II. Called the Big WIG DVD Keeper Series 1, the bundle disc includes full versions of V-Rally '99 and Super Bubsy and demos of Jack Nicklaus 5, HardBall 6 2000 Edition, and Test Drive 5. Full versions of the last three are actually encrypted onto the disc and can be unlocked by purchasing a key from Infogrames for a nominal fee.

"The Big WIG DVD Keeper Series 1 is a model for how content will be delivered to consumers in the digital age,'' said Infogrames director of business development Paul Trowe. "They can demo some of our best titles free of charge and only need to make a quick phone call or an Internet visit to purchase the full versions.''

Viper II boards currently on store shelves should come bundled with the Big WIG DVD Keeper Series 1. The Diamond Viper II comes with a price tag of US$199.
results.lede: Diamond's Viper II will now be bundled with five Infogrames games on one DVD disc.

results.title: Business Week Praises the Dreamcast
results.deck: The Dreamcast recognized as one of the Best Products of 1999 by Business Week magazine.
results.body:
Sega of America announced on Friday that its Dreamcast console has been included as one of the Best Products of 1999 by Business Week magazine. Cited for revolutionary design and technological advances, the Dreamcast console features a modem for Internet capability. Dreamcast titles like NFL2K and Soul Calibur were also mentioned as reason for the system's praise.

"The Sega Dreamcast has had a stellar three months on the market and has sold one million units. We are honored that the respected staff at Business Week magazine recognized the Sega Dreamcast as one of the best for this year," said Peter Moore, senior vice president of Sega of America. "Moving into 2000, we will continue to set new standards in console gaming by being the first gaming company to bring an online gaming experience to a console via the Sega Dreamcast Network."
results.lede: The Dreamcast recognized as one of the Best Products of 1999 by Business Week magazine.

results.title: Hoshigami Pushed Back To Spring
results.deck: Max Five's strategy simulation RPG for the PlayStation has been pushed back from January to spring 2000.
results.body: GameSpot News has learned that the Japanese release of Hoshigami: Ruining Blue Earth (Hoshigami is roughly translated as Star God) for the Sony PlayStation has been pushed back from January to spring 2000. Developed by Max Five, the strategy-simulation-RPG features unique battle systems with a flavor of SquareSoft's Final Fantasy Tactics.
results.lede: Max Five's strategy simulation RPG for the PlayStation has been pushed back from January to spring 2000.

results.title: More PS2 Middleware Technology
results.deck: A new development tool to assist developers in speeding up production times for PC and PlayStation2 games will make designing games easier.
results.body:
A new development tool from Side Effects Software will make designing games on next-generation consoles and PCs a lot easier. Called Proceed3D, the technology consists of a 2D/3D authoring package, a particle runtime engine, and a motion runtime engine, It is intended to allow designers to achieve a high quality of visuals at a fraction of the previously required manpower as well.

"Proceed3D's integrated approach, which bridges content authoring and programming, enables artists to visually create effects and motion without programmer assistance," said Side Effects Software CTO, Paul Salvini. "Neither an authoring solution nor a middleware solution on its own would provide what next-generation console developers require. Proceed3D offers them a streamlined pipeline that will result in film-like quality, faster time to market, less memory use, lower development costs, and portability across multiple platforms."

Side Effects said that it would make the Proceed3D development tool available to PC designers, as well as to PlayStation2 developers as part of Sony's middleware program. Additionally, Side Effects stated that it would announce support for "other consoles later next year," leading us to believe that the company is readying tools for the Nintendo Dolphin as well.

Information on Proceed3D's availability will be revealed this January. In the meantime, Side Effects is offering the technology on a project-by-project royalty basis.
results.lede: A new development tool to assist developers in speeding up production times for PC and PlayStation2 games will make designing games easier.

results.title: Hispanics Protest Toy Story 2 Game
results.deck: Toy Story 2 character sets off Mexican-American protest for alleged stereotyping.
results.body:
A small group of Hispanics led a peaceful demonstration outside Activision's Santa Monica, Calif., headquarters yesterday to protest a character in the Toy Story 2 game. A villain in the game wears a mustache, bullet bandoleer, and a sombrero - all characteristics that the group felt were offensive stereotypes of Mexicans.

Activision developed the game with the Disney Toy Story 2 license, and the character was not from the Toy Story 2 movie. In the end, Disney agreed with the group and regretted the character's presence in the game. A spokesperson for Disney said that it now has plans to change the character "as soon as possible" in a newer version of the game. In the meantime, the game has not been recalled and will remain on retailer shevles.
results.lede: Toy Story 2 character sets off Mexican-American protest for alleged stereotyping.

results.title: Dreamcast Toy Story 2 Confirmed
results.deck: We confirm that the visually impressive Toy Story 2 is coming to the Dreamcast in the near future.
results.body:
The ESRB confirmed it. Online retailer Ebworld confirmed it. And now GameSpot News has confirmed it, as well: Toy Story 2 is coming to the Dreamcast. We've heard from sources inside Activision that the Dreamcast version is nearly complete, and due to the enhanced graphical capabilities of the DC, it looks stellar. The game should be released sometime this winter.

Unfortunately, Activision still refuses to comment on the Dreamcast version of the game. Hopefully, we'll hear official details and see some actual screens soon.
results.lede: We confirm that the visually impressive Toy Story 2 is coming to the Dreamcast in the near future.

results.title: New PlayStation2 X-Fire Screens
results.deck: We've gotten our hands on a few new screens of Electronic Arts Square's first game for the PlayStation2 console.
results.body:
While X-Fire was one of the less impressive games when we played it at this past fall's Tokyo Game Show, Electronic Arts Square has some major time and money invested in the game to make sure it sells. So it's likely that we'll be seeing some major improvements over the next few months.

A PlayStation2 3D corridor shooter similar in style to GoldenEye for the Nintendo 64, X-Fire will make use of some nifty new PlayStation2 effects. In fact, for X-Fire, EA Square has partnered with Animation Science, a company with expertise in the TV/film 3D graphics field. So, no doubt X-Fire will be a title to keep an eye on over the next few months, as it could end up turning out to be a killer app for the PS2. In any case, today we got our hands on a few new screens of the game. These show off some of the characters being generated in real time, and they are definitely worth a look.

X-Fire is currently slated for a release alongside the PlayStation2 when it launches on March 4, 2000, in Japan. The game will also release alongside the US PlayStation2 launch in fall 2000.
results.lede: We've gotten our hands on a few new screens of Electronic Arts Square's first game for the PlayStation2 console.

results.title: Miyamoto Plans GB Advance Zelda
results.deck: Shigeru Miyamoto is currently planning a Zelda title for the next-generation Game Boy system.
results.body:
In an interview with Nintendo's Miyamoto Shigeru in the latest issue of the Japanese gaming magazine Dengekioh, he mentions that he is currently in the planning process for the development of a Zelda title for the Game Boy Advance. While Miyamoto has previously hinted that a Zelda title for the GBA is a distinct possibility, this seems to be the first confirmation that one will really appear.

The Game Boy Advance is Nintendo's next-generation portable game system, scheduled for a release in August 2000 in Japan.
results.lede: Shigeru Miyamoto is currently planning a Zelda title for the next-generation Game Boy system.

results.title: Sid Meier's Anitetam! Releases
results.deck: Firaxis has announced that its latest real-time re-creation of the bloodiest day in Civil War history is now available. Players can order the game through the company's web site (www.firaxis.com) for US$29.99.
results.body: Firaxis has announced that its latest real-time re-creation of the bloodiest day in Civil War history is now available. Players can order the game through the company's web site (www.firaxis.com) for US$29.99.
results.lede: Firaxis has announced that its latest real-time re-creation of the bloodiest day in Civil War history is now available. Players can order the game through the company's web site (www.firaxis.com) for US$29.99.

results.title: Bushnell Joins WebQuest
results.deck: Pong's creator joins Board of Directors of the company that built his latest gaming site.
results.body:
Pong's creator is keeping busy lately. Nolan Bushnell - the father of video gaming, who originally founded Atari and who has since gone on to other tasks - announced today that he will be joining WebQuest International's Board of Directors.

The company runs several web sites, including www.ipong.com, a site that lets gamers play Pong against one another over a browser. In early 2000, players will be able to compete for cash prizes.

"It's flattering to see the renewed interest in Pong after so many years, especially amid all the complex strategy games on the market right now," said Nolan Bushnell. "I'm excited about having an opportunity to participate in its rebirth as an online multiplayer tournament game. I'm also happy to see that the cost of playing a game is still only twenty-five cents." Bushnell will also make an appearance on the ZDTV program Big Thinkers on January 5 at 10:30pm EST to talk about his latest project, uWink.com.
results.lede: Pong's creator joins Board of Directors of the company that built his latest gaming site.

results.title: Creative Loses Aureal Suit
results.deck: A San Francisco jury rules that Aureal's Vortex chips do not infringe on Creative Labs' patent.
results.body:
Last Friday afternoon, a San Francisco jury ruled that Aureal's Vortex chips do not infringe on a Creative Labs patent, clearing the Fremont, Calif., company from a long-standing lawsuit. Originally filed by Creative Labs in February 1998, a day after Aureal announced Vortex design wins with Dell Computers, the suit claimed that Aureal infringed on Creative patent 5,342,990 (titled "digital sampling instrument employing cache-memory") in designing its audio chip.

"Aureal has said from the start that the Vortex products do not infringe on the patent and that the case is motivated by Creative's need to diminish competition in the marketplace at all costs," said Aureal CEO and president Kip Kokinakis. "It is a great victory for Aureal, but also a victory for innovation and competition that we did not yield to a company with vast resources and an intent to eliminate our ability to bring new and exciting products to the market."

However, Creative isn't prepared to accept the ruling and walk away, as the company has announced that it will appeal the court's decision. Meanwhile, Aureal has a patent infringement suit against Creative Labs and is seeking damages and an injunction against sales of the Sound Blaster Live! products. As usual, we'll keep you abreast of all the latest happenings.
results.lede: A San Francisco jury rules that Aureal's Vortex chips do not infringe on Creative Labs' patent.

results.title: Shipping: 3D Prophet DDR-DVI
results.deck: Guillemot's DDR-equipped GeForce 256 card is now available in stores.
results.body:
Guillemot's Hercules 3D Prophet DDR-DVI has started shipping to Canadian and American stores. The board is equipped with double-data-rate SDRAM, which operates at twice the clock rate of standard SDR (single-data-rate) memory found on almost all other video boards and is equipped with a DVI signal out for flat panel monitor users.

The board retails for US$299 after a $20 mail-in rebate - considerably lower than the originally announced price of $399.
results.lede: Guillemot's DDR-equipped GeForce 256 card is now available in stores.

results.title: FFVIII PC Date Announced
results.deck: Square Electronic Arts releases the shipping date of Final Fantasy VIII for the PC.
results.body:
This morning, Square Electronic Arts announced that the PC version of Final Fantasy VIII will begin shipping on January 25, 2000. The game was originally released for the PlayStation in the US on September 9, 1999.

"We are very excited about the upcoming release of Final Fantasy VIII for the PC,'' said Jun Iwasaki, president of Square Electronic Arts. "Now PC players can enjoy the same addictive fun that their PlayStation counterparts experience, with the added benefit of even more stunning graphics and life-like gameplay."

In related news, on January 3, gamers will be able to download a playable version of Chocobo World, a new Windows desktop game, and a noninteractive demo that features the opening sequence of FFVIII. Additionally, Square EA will make two additional interactive demos available for download on January 25, the game's release date.

For more new screenshots of the PC version of FFVIII, visit www.ff8-pc.com.
results.lede: Square Electronic Arts releases the shipping date of Final Fantasy VIII for the PC.

results.title: Online Gaming... $4.9 billion Worth
results.deck: Report claims that online game is going to grow in a big way.
results.body:
According to a Datamonitor report, online gaming in the US and Europe could reach US$4.8 billion by 2004. Of course, US gamers will be responsible for $2.8 billion as the Europeans catch up with $2.1 billion of the total amount.

The report also says that PC-based Internet usage will be the basis for the growth in profits with next-generation Internet-enabled consoles like the Dreamcast pulling up in second place.
results.lede: Report claims that online game is going to grow in a big way.

results.title: Quake III Sales Through the Roof
results.deck: Activision's own numbers put sales of Quake III Arena past the 50,000 mark in only three days.
results.body:
Activision and id Software have announced that, in only the first three days of sales, Quake III Arena has sold upward of 50,000 copies, according to the companies' internal tracking figures.

"Quake is easily one of the hottest brands in interactive entertainment, and we had high expectations for Quake III Arena at launch," said Dusty Welch, Activision's director of global brand management. "If sell-through and reorders are any indication, Quake III Arena is in the position to be the hottest PC game for the holidays".

To date, according to PC Data, Quake II has sold about 610,000 copies and Quake some 550,000 before it. With one million copies of Quake III Arena already manufactured, Activision hopes the game will significantly outsell its two predecessors.
results.lede: Activision's own numbers put sales of Quake III Arena past the 50,000 mark in only three days.
